p.s: Description of Sanguibacter inulinus sp. nov.
Sanguibacter inulinus (i.nu.li'nus. M.L. n. inulum, inulin; M.L. adj. inulinus, pertaining to inulin)
Cells are gram-positive, short, irregularly shaped, motile rods.
Colonies are circular, convex with entire edges, and pale yellow.
Colonies range from 0.5 to 1.0 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation on tryptose soy agar.
Cellulose and Tween 80 are not hydrolyzed.

Acid is produced from glycerol, L-arabinose, ribose, D-xylose, galactose, D-glucose, D-fructose, D-mannose, rhamnose, arbutin, esculin, salicin, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, melibiose, sucrose, trehalose, glycogen, gluconate, β-gentibiose, D-turanose, D-lyxose, α-methy-D-mannoside, α-methyl-D-glucoside, N-acetylglucosamine, amygdalin, inulin, 5-ketogluconate, and D-raffinose.
Acid is not produced from erythritol, D-arabinose, adonitol, sorbitol, L-sorbose, inositol, melezitose, xylitol, D-tagatose, D-fucose, D-arabitol, L-xylose, dulcitol, and 2-ketogluconate.
Some strains produce acid from mannitol and β-methylxyloside.
The cell wall murein type is L-Lys-Ser-D-Glu.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 70.5 mol%.
The type strain is strain ST-50 (= NCFB 3024).
The nucleotide sequence of the 16s rRNA gene of S. inulinus ST-50T (= NCFB 3024T) has been deposited in the EMBL database under accession number X79451.
